title: Shaw Communications adds wireless customers as telco competition intensifies
text:
The Calgary-based firm reported 90,700 new subscribers to its carrier Freedom Mobile as part of its fourth-quarter earnings. That’s a 6.7 per cent increase from the same quarter last year. (The Logic)

Talking point: Freedom’s ability to add customers comes despite Telus, Rogers and Bell all introducing unlimited data plans, something Freedom has long offered. The firm’s growth is partially due to a steady stream of expansions in recent months. In August, for example, it launched in eight cities across Alberta and B.C., regions Telus typically dominates. Bell and Rogers are also fighting smaller carriers in court, seeking to overturn a decision by the Canadian Radio-television and Telecommunications Commission to slash the prices small firms need to pay large ones for internet. London, Ont.-based Start.ca cited that decision for Thursday’s announcement it would lower prices or increasing speeds at no cost for over 14,000 customers. TekSavvy and Distributel have also made similar cuts.

Correction: Bell and Rogers are the major telecoms fighting smaller carriers in court over a CRTC decision. This story has been updated.
